awd_titl_txt: Practice-driven Research: Developing Constructivism-informed Tools for Supporting Learning in Informal Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
Research on how museum staff are trained continues to emerge. Training varies considerably across institutions and typically includes observations, shadowing, and trial and error. While museum educators put high value on increasing visitor-centered participatory experiences, engagement based on acquisition-based theories of learning is still common among floor staff, even after training. Facilitating learning about science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) topics in ways that support visitors in constructing their own understanding is difficult, especially since floor staff/facilitators may be working simultaneously with children and adults of a range of ages, backgrounds, and goals. This project will advance understanding of how to facilitate open-ended learning experiences in ways that engage visitors in practices that align with the STEM disciplines. The project will result in an evidence-based facilitation framework and training modules for training informal science educators. The work is grounded in constructivist theories of learning and identity work and focuses on visitors constructing understanding of STEM topics through active engagement in the practices of STEM. This model also results in learning experiences in informal settings that are mutually reinforcing with the goals of schools. This research is being conducted through an established researcher-practitioner partnership between MOXI, the Wolf Museum of Exploration + Innovation and the University of California at Santa Barbara (UCSB).

The two primary goals of the work are to (1) enable visitors to better engage in STEM practices (practice-based learning) and (2) investigate the role of training in helping facilitators develop the practice-based facilitation strategies needed to support visitors' learning. STEM content in this study is physical science. Prior work resulted in two tools that constitute part of a facilitation framework (a practices-by-engagement matrix and three facilitation pathways) which help educators identify appropriate goals based on how the visitor is engaging with exhibits. The development of the final tool in the framework, facilitation strategies, and the refinement of the first two tools will be done using a design-based implementation research (DBIR) approach. Data collection and analysis will be directed and completed by research-practitioner teams of UCSB graduate students (researchers) and MOXI educators (practitioners); MOXI educators will be both participants and researchers. Data collection activities include: video data using point-of-view cameras worn by visitors and educators; interviews of educators and visitors; observations of the training program; and educator reflections. In the final year, a small field test will be done at six sites, representing different types of museums. Interviews and reflections comprise the data collection at the field sites.  

This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A significant trend in the museum industry has been a shift from object or information-based learning goals to a focus on the visitor experience, enabling learners to construct knowledge through a lens of their prior experiences. This has implications for how exhibits are designed, the textual information posted around the exhibit, and the way the experience is facilitated. Facilitating visitor-centered experiences is challenging. A facilitator must understand the many potential learning opportunities of an exhibit, select one based on an understanding of the learner, and be able to create a bridge between these. This is especially complex in museum settings where facilitators may be working simultaneously with children and adults of a range of ages, backgrounds, and goals. Further, many museum facilitators are part-time staff with few opportunities for training and, while interested in the disciplines represented in the museum, may lack a full understanding of the content. So, it is not surprising that, even in museums with goals of providing visitor-centered participatory experiences, research finds that new facilitators are likely to fall back on facilitation focused on instruction and information delivery.

The University of California, Santa Barbara, and MOXI, The Wolf Museum of Exploration + Innovation, partnered to develop and test a facilitation method and training curriculum to prepare museum facilitators to enact effective visitor-centered facilitation. The goal of this method, Practice-Based Facilitation, is for museum visitors to engage in the practices of a discipline rather than learn specific content. For example, at an interactive science museum, the facilitation goal for a visitor's interaction with an exhibit about magnetism might be for them to engage in developing explanations for what they are observing, testing their ideas, and supporting their claims with evidence. Other types of museums might focus on different practices appropriate for the disciplines aligned with the museum. For example, visitors at a natural history museum observing a diorama representing a natural ecosystem might engage in identifying, categorizing, finding similarities or differences, or making connections to their observations at other museum dioramas. 

The Practice-Based Facilitation method includes work museum facilitators do prior to facilitation and actions taken during interactions with museum visitors. Prior to facilitation, facilitators study the many ways visitors might interact with an exhibit. They do this by observing visitors of different ages and backgrounds as well as engaging with the exhibit themselves. They then identify the various practices that visitors might use during their interactions. During facilitation, facilitators observe how visitors are interacting with the exhibit and then decide between three different facilitation pathways: changing the way in which the visitor interacts with the exhibit, encouraging the visitor to use a practice they do not appear to be using, or helping the visitor to optimize the way in which they are using a practice. These different pathways for facilitation are then supported by tools for facilitators that include specific verbal prompts and questioning strategies. 

This project developed and tested three models of a training program to meet the needs of different museums: (1) a year-long apprentice program that included weekly coursework and homework alongside part-time work as a museum facilitator; (2) a curriculum that included 4 two-hour training modules coupled with 10 hours of applied improvisation training; and (3) five one-hour training modules that could be implemented as discrete training activities to focus on specific Practice-Based Facilitation topics. Workshops and instructional material to prepare museum personnel to train staff using the second model were developed and field tested at 5 institutions, including a botanic garden, a natural history museum, a science center, and two children's museums. The first and third models were tested at MOXI.

Research on facilitators and interviews with field testers led to deeper understanding about museum educator training. In particular, while the longer training in Practice-Based Facilitation led to facilitators engaging in effective facilitation, the shorter training sessions had less of an impact. Applied improvisation training by professional instructors was identified as a key component of facilitator training. In addition, disciplinary practices appropriate for a variety of museums were identified. Finally, this project led to understanding related to conducting joint work across museums and universities. 

This project directly impacted the facilitator training at 6 museums and thereby impacted visitors to these museums. Practices related to children?s museums, natural history museums, and botanic gardens as well as practices specific to climate change education that might occur at these museums were identified. These practices can be built on and adopted by other types of institutions. The activities and results of this project have been shared through a public resource website; peer-reviewed publications; conference presentations; local, national, and virtual workshops; and an online video. Graduate and undergraduate students, museum floor staff, and museum leaders were involved in the development, implementation, testing, and research on this project and had opportunities to network across educational sectors.
